Column Comment.0: STRAT NAME SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the stratigraphic name set. Astratigraphic name set is an unordered collection of stratigraphic units, that may be inuse for a Lexicon, a geographic area, a project, a company etc.
Column Comment.1: STRATIGRAPHIC UNIT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the stratigraphic unit.
Column Comment.2: DESCRIPTION SEQUENCE NUMBER: unique number for the sequence of thedescription.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: AVERAGE VALUE: the average value associated with this stratigraphic unitdescription. In this case, the definition could be technical in nature.
Column Comment.7: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format colums, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.8: DESCRIPTION: Textual description of the stratigraphic unit. It is generally preferableto use the codified descriptions.
Column Comment.9: DESCRIPTION DATE: the date that the description was made.
Column Comment.10: STRATIGRAPHIC DESCRIPTION TYPE: the type of descriptive informationincluded, usually classified as found in a stratigraphic lexicon. Categories mayinclude Lithologic Characteristics, Thickness and Distribution, Relationships toOtherUnits, History etc.
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: MAXIMUM VALUE: the maximum value associated with this stratigraphic unitdescription. In this case, the definition could be technical in nature.
Column Comment.16: MINIMUM VALUE: the minimum value associated with this stratigraphic unitdescription. In this case, the definition could be technical in nature.
Column Comment.19: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.20: REFERENCED PAGES: the pages in the source document text that were used toobtain the description of the strat unit. Typically, this would be a lexicon.
Column Comment.21: REMARK: narrative remarks about the description of the stratigraphic unit.
Column Comment.22: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.23: SOURCE DOCUMENT: A list of documents that are used as the source for supplyingdata. Source documents may include government and regulatory forms, operatorreports or scout tickets, publications, news letters, books or jounals.
Column Comment.24: STRATIGRAPHIC UNIT DESCRIPTION: any descriptive charateristic of thestratigraphic unit, such as the color or texture that may be used to identify thestratigraphic unit. Likely to be replaced in future work.
Column Comment.25: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.26: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.27: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.28: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.29: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.30: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.31: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
